body:
We now display relative time for event as

```
FIRSTSEEN   LASTSEEN
14m         14m 
```

But when using `kubectl get ev --watch` the relative time is caculated everytime when the event is printed, in this case for some event occured almost same time, the printed time may be different. 

with wacth:

```
18s       18s       1         nginx-controller-9pu4x   Pod  
19s       19s       1         nginx-controller-nqm00   Pod  
19s       19s       1         nginx-controller-axvdl   Pod  
20s       20s       1         nginx-controller-tbrjs   Pod  
20s       20s       1         nginx-controller-q3go7   Pod  
21s       21s       1         nginx-controller-7hrjm   Pod 
21s       21s       1         nginx-controller-s94rd   Pod  
21s       21s       1         nginx-controller-9pu4x   Pod 
21s       21s       1         nginx-controller-s94rd   Pod  
22s       22s       1         nginx-controller-axvdl   Pod 
```

with get:

```
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-nqm00   Pod 
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-kwinh   Pod 
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-9pu4x   Pod 
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-7hrjm   Pod 
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-7hrjm   Pod 
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-7hrjm   Pod  
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-q2xz9   Pod 
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-s94rd   Pod
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-s94rd   Pod 
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-q3go7   Pod 
45s         45s        1         nginx-controller-tbrjs   Pod  
```

with watch it seems these events are not happening at same time, it will give user a misunderstanding and is not helpful.

Should we print the abolute time for event in this case?

@kubernetes/kubectl @jiangyaoguo
title: Display absolute time for event when using --watch
